alert.note: Alert for Admiralty Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Juneau; City and Borough of Sitka; City and Borough of Wrangell; City of Hyder; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Municipality of Skagway; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 17 at 10:50AM AKST by NWS Juneau
info.description: ...POTENTIALLY IMPACTFUL SNOW EVENT EARLY NEXT WEEK... We continue to monitor the possibility of a significant snow event for portions of Southeast Alaska beginning Sunday afternoon and extending into Tuesday. Cold air moves into the region this weekend with increasing north winds across the panhandle. Early next week there is high confidence on a low moving north into the Gulf of Alaska spreading moisture and advecting warmer air over the colder airmass. The main concern regarding this event will be how far east the low is as it moves into the Gulf. A track further east will allow moisture and warmer air to expand further north. Meanwhile, a track further west will limit how far north the moisture and warming spreads. Average (around 40%) confidence the southern panhandle will see snow accumulations of 1 to 2 inches before changing to rain Monday. The biggest challenge is from Sumner Strait north through the Icy Strait corridor. High confidence (75%) in widespread snow amounts of 3 to 5 inches with lower probabilities (25%) of 8 to 12 inches across this region Monday into Tuesday. Although some uncertainty remains on where the impacts will be greatest, community decision makers who are responsible for planning snow removal and school administrators who are tasked with declaring snow days are encouraged to remain abreast of changes to the forecast through the weekend. As always, the latest forecast information can be found at www.weather.gov/Juneau.
